PageElement.TextBox:
In this lesson you will move through a number of information pages which will teach you about The Collection Principle.

You will also be presented with scenario pages, where a situation will be described involving a number of fictitious characters. You will be asked questions which will test your understanding of The Collection Principle.

These questions are not scored and your response is not recorded. Use the feedback provided to consolidate what you have learned during this lesson.

Click on the Quick Facts menu button above to view a summary of points covered in the lesson.

PageElement.TextBox:
This lesson should take about 20 minutes.
 
You will learn about the Collection Principle which sets out the rules for the collection of personal information.
 
At the end of this lesson you should have a good understanding of:
 
  • when you can collect personal information
  • the ways in which you can and cannot collect personal information
  • what you should tell individuals when collecting information from them
  • what information is specially sensitive and the special rules that apply to it
 
When you are ready click on the next button below to start training.

The Collection Principle is very important. It sets out rules for the collection of personal information.
 
Its objective is to ensure that individuals know who is collecting their information and why. This allows individuals to make informed choices about disclosing their personal details and to control who gets that information.
 
The Collection Principle applies to all personal information collected by your organisation after 21 December 2001.

You can only collect personal information that is necessary for one or more of your organisation's functions or activities.
 
No-one sets out to collect unnecessary information. But the reasons for asking for something may be forgotten, or change, so it is useful to consider whether every piece of information is actually needed.
 
You must only collect personal information by lawful and fair means and not in an unreasonably intrusive way.

Page.Title: So what are the rules about collecting personal information?

PageElement.TextBox:
You can only collect personal information that is necessary for one or more of your organisation's functions or activities.
 
No-one sets out to collect unnecessary information. But the reasons for asking for something may be forgotten, or change, so it is useful to consider whether every piece of information is actually needed.
 
You must only collect personal information by lawful and fair means and not in an unreasonably intrusive way.
 
"Lawful means" are methods that are not prohibited by law. Unlawful means would include telephone intercepts or trespass. Unfair methods would include intimidation or deception. Covert or surreptitious collection would not usually be fair, but it may be allowed under the law in certain circumstances, for instance, in the investigation of wrongdoing.
 
If it is reasonable and practicable to do so, your organisation must collect personal information about an individual only from that individual (rather than from third parties).
 
If you believe that the collection of information from individuals will not be reasonable and practicable and you want to collect this information from a third party, you should check this first with the appropriate person in your organisation.
 
Click here to view the full text of the Collection Principle

When you collect information from individuals, you must take reasonable steps to make them aware of all of the following information:
 
  • the name of your organisation and how to contact it
  • that individuals are able to access the information held about them
  • the purposes of collection
  • the organisations or types of organisations that your organisation usually gives this information to
  • if the information is required by law
  • the main consequences, if any, for the individual if they do not provide you with the information
 
If you collect information about an individual from a third party, you must still take reasonable steps to ensure the individual is aware of the information listed above.
 
If you think this will be difficult for any reason or you are not sure how to go about doing this, you should talk to an appropriate person in your organisation.
 
Exception to the Notice Requirements
 
The notice requirements are varied in the case of related companies.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
Click here to view a definition of related companies
  • Two companies are related if:
    • one company is a holding company of the other company;
    • one company is a subsidiary of the other; or
    • they are sister companies, that is, they share the same parent company.
     
    If you have any questions about whether your organisation is related to another company, you should contact the legal department.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
If you have any queries about whether your organisation is related to another company, you should contact an appropriate person in your organisation.
 
If your organisation collects personal information (excluding sensitive information) from a related company, it does not need to notify individuals of the information listed above where the related company that originally collected the personal information notified the individuals that it may provide their personal information to its related companies.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
Click here to view a definition of sensitive information
  • Sensitive information means any information relating to an individual's:
    • health
    • racial or ethnic origin
    • political opinions
    • membership of a political association, professional or trade association or trade union
    • religious beliefs or affiliations
    • philosophical beliefs
    • sexual preferences or practices
    • criminal record
    [Hide]

Page.Title: How can you meet the notice requirements?

PageElement.TextBox:
The Privacy Act allows you to meet the notice requirement in various ways - the important thing is to ensure individuals are made aware of the relevant points.
 
The most common way of complying with the notice requirement will be by providing a privacy statement whenever information is collected, e.g. in paper or electronic forms.
 
If some of the matters required to be notified are obvious, or if they are already covered elsewhere, it may not be necessary to repeat them.
 
Information is often obtained by telephone and it can be difficult to satisfy all of the notice requirements on first contact. The Privacy Act acknowledges this by allowing notice to be given "as soon as practicable" after collection. So, it may be appropriate to notify individuals of some or all of the matters in a mail out following an initial telephone contact. However, you must always keep in mind that the objective is to give individuals the ability to make an informed choice, so they need to be given as much detail as possible before any personal information is collected.

The collection of sensitive information is subject to special conditions.
 
Sensitive information means any information relating to an individual's:
 
  • health
  • racial or ethnic origin
  • political opinions
  • membership of a political association, professional or trade association or trade union
  • religious beliefs or affiliations
  • philosophical beliefs
  • sexual preferences or practices
  • criminal record

Page.Title: Special rules for collecting sensitive information

PageElement.TextBox:
The collection of sensitive information is subject to special conditions.
 
Sensitive information means any information relating to an individual's:
 
  • health
  • racial or ethnic origin
  • political opinions
  • membership of a political association, professional or trade association or trade union
  • religious beliefs or affiliations
  • philosophical beliefs
  • sexual preferences or practices
  • criminal record
 
Sensitive information can only be collected:
 
  • if the individual consents
  • where it is required to be collected by law, or
  • in a health emergency.
 
Health information can be collected in some additional circumstances. Health information is subject to specific State law in certain jurisdictions as well as the Privacy Act.
 
Click here to view the full text of the Sensitive Information Principle

Now it's time to get you thinking about how the Collection Principle works in practice.
 
On the next few screens are some imaginary scenarios for you to read.
 
Then have a go at answering some practice questions. Your answers will not be recorded or scored.
 
Here goes...

Cameron is the marketing director of 'Flying High', a chain of budget travel agencies. A lot of travel advice and travel bookings are done over the phone or via the internet. Cameron has proposed that the company starts recording inquiry calls for training purposes and to obtain information on customer expectations and needs for the purposes of marketing.

PageElement.FreeTextQA:
Do you think there is any problem with this? If so what is the problem?
If you mentioned that the collection might be unlawful or unfair and that disclosure is required, you are on the right track.
 
If Flying High is prepared to be open with callers about recording conversations, it can comply with the Collection Principle. But if Flying High does not do this, the collection would be unfair and probably also unlawful under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act.
 
Flying High would also need to comply with the notice requirements as it is creating a record of personal information.

PageElement.TextBox:
Stacey is the manager of Zen, a dynamic chain of boutique hotels. To improve customer service, Stacey has decided to place 'guest surveys' in all rooms. The survey forms state that Zen is collecting information for the purpose of improving its customer service. The survey forms ask for information about a guest's level of satisfaction. They also ask for details about a guest's occupation, religious beliefs, wage bracket, age and lifestyle.
 
The survey is headed "Confidential Survey" and there is no space for a guest's name or contact details. This gives the impression that it is an anonymous survey. However, there is a unique reference number on each survey to allow Zen to match the replies to known clients.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
Click here for a useful tip
  • Hints and Tips
    The Survey must contain the following information:
     
    • how to contact Zen
    • that individuals are able to access the information held about them
    • the purpose of collection
    • the organisations or types of organisations that Zen usually gives this information to
    • if the information is required by law
    • the main consequences, if any, for the individual if they don't provide you with the information.
    [Hide]

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
If Zen implements this idea, which (if any) part of the Collection Principle would they breach?
(a) unlawful collection
Possibly. This might also be considered misleading and deceptive conduct in breach of the Trade Practices Act.
(b) unfair collection
You are correct! This would be unfair because guests would have been misled and deceived. It may also be a breach of the Trade Practices Act (which prohibits misleading and deceptive conduct).
(c) failure to meet the notice requirements
You are correct! The survey form does not cover all the matters required to be notified to individuals.
(d) unnecessary collection
Possibly. Details such as a guest's occupation, wage bracket, age and lifestyle might not be necessary for Zen to determine ways to improve its customer service.

PageElement.TextBox: David and Neeta are business managers for the accounting firm 'Speedy Returns'. During their weekly strategy meeting they brainstorm ideas on new sources of potential clients. Neeta is worried that the Privacy Act will stop them from getting information about potential clients from other organisations.

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
Which of the following statements is correct?
(a) Speedy Returns can only obtain leads directly from individuals, such as from responses to advertisements or through Speedy Returns' web site
You are incorrect.
 
The Collection Principle only requires collection directly from individuals where it is "reasonable and practicable". It is not intended to stop lead generation although the organisation that originally collected the information must have complied with the notice requirements so that individuals are aware that their details may be passed on to Speedy Returns.
 
Speedy Returns will have to take reasonable steps to comply with the notice requirements concerning its collection of information which includes notifying individuals of its name and how to contact it and the purposes of collection. It may be that if the original collecting organisation has disclosed this information already on behalf of Speedy Returns, then Speedy Returns will not need to do so.
 
It can be complicated to work out whether notice requirements have been met so if you want to collect information from third parties, you should consult your legal and compliance manager first.
(b) Speedy Returns can continue to receive lists of prospects from third parties
You are correct, but only where it is not "reasonable and practicable" to collect information directly from individuals.
 
The Collection Principle is not intended to stop lead generation although the organisation that originally collected the information must have complied with the notice requirements so that individuals are aware that their details may be passed on to Speedy Returns.
 
If the original collecting organisation did not make individuals aware of the notice requirements as it relates to Speedy Returns, Speedy Returns will have to take reasonable steps to provide individuals with the information required by the notice requirements.
 
It can be complicated to work out whether notice requirements have been met so if you want to collect information from third parties, you should consult your legal and compliance manager first.

PageElement.TextBox:
Raoul is a legal officer at Hightech, an innovative software company, that tailor makes programs for individual clients. The company has a standard questionnaire which it uses to obtain information about the work practices of individual employees of its clients. Information collected from each employee ranges from the employee's level of education to level of computer literacy.
 
Raoul has been asked to draft a privacy notice to include in the standard questionnaire.

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
Which of the following details does the Privacy Act require to be included in the privacy notice?
(a) how to contact Hightech
You are correct! This is one of the details that individuals must be made aware of when personal information is collected.
(b) Hightech's Australian Business Number
You are incorrect. This is not required by the Privacy Act, but a company must set out its ACN or ABN with its name on all public documents to comply with the Corporations Act 2001.
(c) the purpose of collection
You are correct! This is one of the details that individuals must be made aware of when personal information is collected.
(d) organisations to whom Hightech usually discloses the information
You are correct! This is one of the details that individuals must be made aware of when personal information is collected.
(e) what line of business Hightech is in
This would only need to be included if it is necessary for individuals to understand the purposes for which Hightech is collecting their personal information.

PageElement.TextBox: Raoul sends the draft privacy notice to Christina, head of marketing for feedback.

PageElement.FreeTextQA:
Is there anything else Christina should include in Hightech's privacy notice on its questionnaire?
You are right if you mentioned that Christina should include:
 
  • the identity of Hightech as the collecting organisation;
  • that individuals are able to access information held about them by Hightech;
  • whether the information is required to be collected by law; and
  • the main consequences, if any, for the individual if they do not provide their information.

PageElement.TextBox:
Dawn is a salesperson for Bricks & Mortar, a supplier of home building materials. Dawn's salary depends on the number of customers she attracts to Bricks and Mortar. Her de-facto, Bruce, who works for a local council, lets her have a list of names and addresses of individuals who have been successful in obtaining development approvals for their homes.
 
Over a six-month period, without telling them what she knows about them or where she got their names, Dawn gets 15 people to buy building materials from Bricks & Mortar.

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
Dawn's manager Fiona finds out about this. What should Fiona do?
(a) sack Dawn
The Privacy Act does not require this, but Fiona may want to consider this disciplinary action.
 
Bricks & Mortar is liable for anything Dawn, as an employee, does in the course of her work, unless it is something that she has been specifically instructed not to do. Bricks & Mortar would be liable for breaching the Collection Principle by collecting information by unlawful means and, in the process, failing to meet the notification requirements.
(b) give her an extra bonus
Certainly not - though this may have happened before the Privacy Act.
 
Bricks & Mortar is liable for anything Dawn, as an employee, does in the course of her work, unless it is something that she has been specifically instructed not to do. Bricks & Mortar would be liable for breaching the Collection Principle by collecting information by unlawful means and, in the process, failing to meet the notification requirements.
(c) ensure that the practice stops and that all staff are reminded that this is unlawful
You are correct! This is a very serious breach of the Privacy Act.
 
Bricks & Mortar is liable for anything Dawn, as an employee, does in the course of her work, unless it is something that she has been specifically instructed not to do. Bricks & Mortar would be liable for breaching the Collection Principle by collecting information by unlawful means and, in the process, failing to meet the notification requirements.
(d) notify all the clients and apologise
The Privacy Act does not require this but Fiona may want to consider it.
 
Bricks & Mortar is liable for anything Dawn, as an employee, does in the course of her work, unless it is something that she has been specifically instructed not to do. Bricks & Mortar would be liable for breaching the Collection Principle by collecting information by unlawful means and, in the process, failing to meet the notification requirements.

PageElement.TextBox: Sophia is the marketing director of a rapidly growing recruitment agency 'Beyond'. Sophia is wondering what notice must be given to clients about the information being collected when they call Beyond. Does Sophia need to make sure that Laura, the receptionist, notifies clients of the information that is required to be disclosed by the Collection Principle when she collects personal information from clients over the phone?

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
Which of the following is the correct answer?
(a) Yes, either Laura, the receptionist or a recorded message must give all these details
You are incorrect.
 
The Privacy Act allows notice to be given as soon as practicable after collection. So, if it is not reasonable to give all of this information over the phone, the remaining information should be provided at the next possible opportunity, such as in a mail out following the initial telephone contact.
(b) No, at least some of the details may be given in writing later
You are correct!
 
The Privacy Act allows notice to be given as soon as practicable after collection. So, it may be appropriate to notify individuals of some of the matters at the next possible opportunity, such as in a mail out following an initial telephone contact if it is not practicable to give out all the information over the phone.

PageElement.TextBox:
Siobhan is the marketing manager for 'Upstart' a medium sized internet service provider. She has just completed her privacy training and is reviewing the procedures Upstart already has in place.
 
It has occurred to her that when potential customers make inquiries to Upstart's call centres, Upstart's customer service representatives ask for the caller's name, to make their service more personal. If the customer does not want further information forwarded to them or does not wish to make any further inquiries, the customer's name is not recorded.
 
Siobhan thinks it would be a waste of time to make all of the disclosures required under the Privacy Act in this situation.

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
What advice would you give to Siobhan?
(a) Although providing all the disclosure details may be inconvenient, it is required by law.
You are incorrect.
 
The Privacy Act only applies to personal information that is contained in a record. Unless the customer service representatives are recording identifiable personal information about the caller in some way, such as entering it into a database, the Privacy Act does not apply.
(b) You do not need to provide all the disclosure details as the caller's personal information is not being recorded.
You are correct!
 
The Privacy Act only applies to personal information that is collected for inclusion or held in a record. Unless the customer service representatives are keeping a record of personal information about the caller, such as entering it into a database or writing the information down, the Privacy Act does not apply.

PageElement.TextBox:
Congratulations! You have completed your lesson.
 
Click the End Lesson button to exit the lesson.
